questions.correct_answer: D. Desmopressin is used for both pituitary and renal diabetes insipidus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Desmopressin is used for both pituitary and renal diabetes insipidus Desmopressin works by replacing vasopressin a hormone that is normally produced in the body to help balance the amount of water and salt .

questions.text: Desmopressin is a V2 selective agonist and it is used in all the following conditions except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal varices Desmopressin is V2 receptor selective and not effective in esophageal varices Terlipressin is V1 receptor-selective, so better than desmopressin for esophageal variceal bleeding due to its constructive property. Desmopressin is the drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus and is used in nocturnal enuresis in children, haemophilia and von Willebrand’s Disease

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient was having Dilutional Hyponatremia and increased ADH levels. Which of the following drug will help in the above condition of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tolvaptan Patients having Dilutional Hyponatremia and increased ADH levels point towards a diagnosis of SIADH. V2 receptor antagonists like tolvaptan are used in SIADH PHARMACOKINETICS The absolute bioavailability of a dose of tolvaptan is unknown, but at least 40% of the drug is absorbed after oral administration. The onset of effect is two to four hours after a dose is taken, and peak effects occur four to eight hours after administration. After absorption, it is 99% bound to circulating plasma proteins. The volume of distribution is approximately 3 L/kg

Highyeild:

Advantages of Tolvaptan Improves signs and symptoms of congestion Improves hyponatremia No effect on renal functions No effect on blood pressure No effect on electrolytes Oral route of administration No adverse effect on mortality Demeclocycline is also used in the treatment of SIADH For nephrogenic DI where the kidney is unresponsive to ADH, DOC is thiazides , other drugs used are Amiloride( DOC for Lithium induced diabetes insipidus) carbamazepine and Chlorpropamide

questions.text: 40/Male c/o liver cirrhosis presents to the opd with abdominal distension and pedal edema increasing since last few days. The doctor prescribes a furosemide diuretic to decrease the edema. Which of the following must be added to increase furosemide efficacy:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spironolactone It is used in combination with other medications to treat high bp and heart failure in order to reduce the risk of strokes and heart failure. MECHANISM OF ACTION

Highyeild:

In patients with cirrhotic and nephrotic edema, there are high chances of furosemide resistance due to hyperaldosteronism. However, the addition of spironolactone helps overcome the resistance and hence improves the efficacy of furosemide.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after presenting with elevated blood pressure readings during her last two visits. After her last visit 2 months ago, she tried controlling her hypertension with weight loss before starting medical therapy, but she has since been unable to lose any weight. Her pulse is 76/min, and her blood pressure is 154/90 mm Hg on the right arm and 155/93 mm Hg on the left arm. She agrees to start treatment with a thiazide diuretic. In response to this treatment, which of the following is most likely to decrease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urinary calcium excretion Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) can increase serum calcium levels by decreasing the excretion of calcium in the urine. Other adverse effects include hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. The inhibition of renal Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal tubule causes a net urine loss of positive ions such as sodium. This is compensated by increased renal tubular reabsorption of calcium to maintain electrochemical balance. Thiazide diuretics are used mainly in the treatment of hypertension, but their effect on serum and urinary calcium concentration can also be used for the management of osteoporosis and the prevention of calcium kidney stones.

Highyeild:

CIASSIFICATION Thiazide Diuretics Chlorthiazide Hydrochlorthiazide Loop Diuretics Furosemide Ethacrynic acid Potassium sparing Diuretics Spirinolactone Amiloride Triamterene Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors Acetazolamide Dorzolamide

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Thiazide and most other diuretics decrease serum sodium concentration by increasing the loss of sodium in the urine. The diuretic effect of thiazides is due to the decreased reabsorption of renal Na+, which creates an osmotic gradient for fluid to be excreted in the urine. Option: C. Thiazides and most other diuretics (except potassium-sparing agents) increase potassium excretion in the urine due to the increased exchange of potassium for sodium via the Na+-K+ cotransporter in the late distal tubule. To avoid hypokalemia, thiazide diuretics may be combined with potassium-sparing diuretics. Option: D. Thiazide diuretics increase total serum cholesterol levels, mildly increase low-density lipoproteins, and increase triglyceride levels. Thiazides do not have a substantial effect on high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.
